in the s bosnia and herzegovina experienced a brutal war following the breakup of yugoslavia the conflict known as the bosnian war lasted from april  to december  and was part of the series of yugoslav wars that occurred after the disintegration of the socialist federal republic of yugoslaviakey events and characteristics of the bosnian war include ethnic tensions the war was predominantly a territorial conflict between three main ethnic groups in bosnia and herzegovina bosniaks bosnian muslims serbs orthodox christians and croats catholics these groups had coexisted relatively peacefully during the years of yugoslav unity but nationalist sentiments grew stronger following the economic and political decline of yugoslavia in the late s independence following a referendum on independence on february march   which was boycotted by the majority of bosnian serbs bosnia and herzegovina declared independence from yugoslavia the declaration was recognized by the european community and the united states but was opposed by bosnian serbs who sought to remain in a serbdominated yugoslavia outbreak of war the bosnian serbs supported by the serbian government under slobodan milošević armed themselves and formed their own entity republika srpska and began to seize territory the conflict quickly escalated into a fullscale war siege of sarajevo the capital of bosnia sarajevo was besieged by bosnian serb forces for nearly four years becoming one of the longest sieges in modern history the city suffered thousands of civilian casualties and extensive destruction of infrastructure ethnic cleansing a tragic feature of the war was the systematic practice of ethnic cleansing characterized by the forced displacement of people from their homes mass killings and atrocities committed against civilian populations particularly by bosnian serb forces srebrenica massacre in july  one of the wars most horrific events took place when bosnian serb forces under the command of general ratko mladić overran the unprotected safe area of srebrenica and subsequently murdered more than  bosniak men and boys in what was later declared an act of genocide by the aspects of carters time in office energy crisis and policy    carter addressed the energy crisis that peaked in the late s by promoting energy conservation and the development of alternative energy sources he established the department of energy in     he also delivered a famous speech known as the crisis of confidence speech or malaise speech although he never used the word malaise where he discussed the nations energy crisis and the need for energy reform economic policies    carters administration faced inflation and unemployment economic issues often referred to as stagflation he appointed paul volcker as the chairman of the federal reserve who implemented monetary policies that eventually helped curb inflation but also led to a recession    carter attempted to control inflation through voluntary wage and price controls foreign affairs    carters most celebrated foreign policy achievement was the brokering of the camp david accords between israel and egypt in  leading to the egyptisrael peace treaty in     in  carter allowed the deposed shah of iran to enter the us for medical treatment which sparked the iran hostage crisis militants seized the us embassy in tehran and held  american diplomats and citizens hostage for  days the crisis lasted beyond carters presidency    carters administration also negotiated the salt ii treaty with the soviet union to limit nuclear arms but faced opposition in congress and the treaty was never ratified    the carter doctrine was a policy that declared that the united states would use military force if necessary to defend its national interests in the persian gulf region human rights focus    carter emphasized human rights in his foreign policy seeking to move away from supporting authoritarian regimes that were allies of the united states but had poor human rights records    his commitment to human rights influenced international relations and us foreign aid programs during and after his presidency panama canal treaty    carter supported and signed the panama canal treaties which transferred control of the canal from the united states to panama the treaties were controversial and met with significant opposition but they were ratified by the senate environmental conservation    carter championed environmental conservation by expanding the national park system and by signing the alaska national interest lands conservation act which protected vast areas of alaskan wilderness deregulation    his administration pursued deregulation in several industries including the airlines railroads and telecommunications which had longterm impacts on those sectorsafter losing the reelection bid in  to ronald reagan carter went on to become a prominent human rights activist and founded the carter center in  a nonprofit organization that addresses international conflicts disease prevention and other global issues he has also been involved in various humanitarian efforts and has served as an election observer in countries transitioning to democracy carter was awarded the nobel peace prize in  for his work to find peaceful solutions to international conflicts advance democracy and human rights and promote economic and social development

the political structure of china is a oneparty socialist republic with chinese characteristics which means it is heavily influenced by the ideology and governance of the chinese communist party ccp the key features of the political structure are as follows the chinese communist party ccp the ccp is the ruling and sole legal political party in china it leads and directs all aspects of chinese political and societal life the partys leadership is central and its general secretary is the most powerful person in china currently xi jinping as of my knowledge cutoff in  the state council this is the chief administrative body of the peoples republic of china and is led by the premier it is roughly equivalent to the government or the cabinet in other countries the state council is responsible for implementing policies and legislation as developed by the ccp and legislated by the national peoples congress the national peoples congress npc as chinas highest state body and its unicameral legislative house the npc has the power to legislate oversee the operations of the government and elect major officers of state delegates to the npc are elected for fiveyear terms although in practice they are largely controlled by the ccp the president the president is the head of state in china elected by the national peoples congress while this role is largely ceremonial the president plays a role in diplomatic activities and symbolic national functions since the constitution was amended to remove term limits for the president the role can be held indefinitely subject to the support of the ccp and the current president xi jinping also serves as the general secretary of the ccp consolidating his position as chinas paramount leader the central military commission this body controls the peoples liberation army pla the armed forces of china the chairman of the central military commission has control over the military and is often also the general secretary of the ccp which is another role held by xi jinping further centralizing military and political power judiciary china has a system of courts and a legal framework that includes various levels of peoples courts prosecuting offices and legal supervision however the legal system is heavily influenced by the party and the judiciary is not independent as it is in some other countries regions and local government china is divided into provinces autonomous regions and municipalities directly under the central government these regions have their own local governments and party committees but are ultimately subject to central control united front this refers to a coalition of parties and organizations led by the ccp that work towards the party’s goals it includes eight legally permitted minor parties which all support the leadership of the communist party and have no actual governing powerin summary chinas political structure is defined by its concentration of power in the ccp and strong central control with the formal apparatus of state functioning within the parameters set by party leadership

galileo galilei the italian astronomer is renowned for his pioneering use of the telescope for astronomical observations which he began in  upon turning his telescope to the night sky galileo made several groundbreaking discoveries that challenged the prevailing geocentric model of the cosmos where earth was believed to be the center of the universe some of the significant celestial objects and phenomena galileo observed include the moons surface galileo saw that the moons surface was not smooth and perfect as had been previously assumed instead he observed mountains craters and valleys much like the earths terrain the phases of venus he observed venus going through a full set of phases similar to the moon this observation supported the heliocentric model of the solar system proposed by copernicus as it showed that venus orbited the sun not the earth jupiters moons galileo discovered four large moons orbiting jupiter now known as the galilean moons io europa ganymede and callisto this was significant because it provided evidence of celestial bodies that did not orbit the earth challenging the geocentric view the milky way he observed that the milky way was composed of a vast number of stars packed so densely that they appeared as clouds to the naked eye sunspots galileo noted dark spots on the surface of the sun which changed over time the observation of sunspots indicated that the sun was not an unchanging perfect sphere as had been widely believed saturns shape when galileo first observed saturn the resolution of his telescope was not sufficient to clearly make out the rings instead he reported it as having ears or handles later observations and improvements in telescope technology led to the understanding that saturn has a ring systemthese discoveries by galileo provided substantial support for the heliocentric view of the solar system and greatly advanced the field of astronomy shaping the scientific revolution they were published in his famous work sidereus nuncius the starry messenger in

the term egfr african american on a blood test refers to estimated glomerular filtration rate specifically adjusted for individuals who identify as african american the egfr is a calculation based on a serum creatinine test along with other factors such as age sex and sometimes weight and height it is used to estimate how well the kidneys are filtering waste from the bloodcreatinine is a waste product that comes from normal wear and tear on muscles of the body and healthy kidneys filter creatinine out of the blood when the kidneys are not functioning properly the level of creatinine in the blood will risethe formula to calculate egfr takes into account that african americans on average have higher muscle mass compared to other racial groups which results in higher normal creatinine levels and consequently a higher egfr therefore the equation includes a correction factor for this population to more accurately represent their kidney functionit is important to recognize that the same level of creatinine in the blood could signify different egfr values for african americans compared to other ethnic groups due to this adjustment egfr is a critical measurement for diagnosing and managing kidney diseases and understanding these differences helps health professionals provide more personalized and accurate care

alexander graham bell was a prolific inventor and scientist beyond his most famous invention the telephone heres a list of some other inventions and contributions bell made to various fields photophone bells invention of the photophone was a precursor to modern fiberoptic communications systems it was a device that could transmit sound on a beam of light and while it wasnt practical at the time it certainly pointed the way toward future communication technologies graphophone together with charles sumner tainter bell developed the graphophone which was a device that could record and play back sound it was an improvement on thomas edisons phonograph and used waxcoated cylinders for recording metal detector bell invented an early version of the metal detector in  which he tried unsuccessfully to use to find the bullet inside president james garfield after he had been shot aileron in aeronautics bell contributed to the refinement of control surfaces for aircraft most notably the aileron which is a crucial technology used on the wings of aircraft to assist with turning and stability in flight hydrofoils bell also worked on fast boats and is credited with developing technology that led to the hydrofoil—a boat or ship that has winglike structures on its hull to lift the vessels body out of the water reducing drag and allowing for greater speeds tetrahedral kites he experimented with tetrahedral kites which consisted of multiple triangular cells stacked together these kite structures were part of his research into flying machines and the possibility of manned flight hd bells fascination with speed led him to work on the development of the hd a hydrofoil boat that set a marine speed record in  audiometer he also created devices for detecting hearing problems and for teaching speech to the deaf which stemmed from both his personal interest his wife and mother were deaf and professional interest in acoustics and speechalexander graham bells contributions went well beyond the invention of the telephone impacting fields such as aviation marine engineering and medical technology he also dedicated a significant portion of his life to working with the deaf including helen keller and founded the american association to promote the teaching of speech to the deaf now the alexander graham bell association for the deaf and hard of hearing

the roman empire had an autocratic form of government where power was concentrated in the hands of a single ruler—the emperor the system evolved from the roman republic which had been characterized by a mixed constitution with consuls the senate and popular assemblies sharing powerthe transformation from a republic to an empire began with julius caesars appointment as dictator for life in  bce which upset the balance of power and led to his assassination the ensuing power struggles culminated in the rise of augustus known also as octavian who became the first emperor of rome in  bce after the defeat of mark antony and cleopatra this marked the beginning of the principate period which is characterized by rulers who maintained a façade of republican government while holding ultimate authoritythe principate  bce   ce was characterized by the emperors holding significant power but nonetheless still utilizing the existing republican institutions the emperor had control over the military the final judicial authority and the power to enact laws he also held the authority to appoint senators and other officials despite this concentration of power the emperors often presented themselves as merely first among equals the princeps in theory the senate still had significant authority but in practice its power was substantially diminished as the emperors consolidated controlthe later period of the roman empire known as the dominate from around  ce onward saw greater authoritarianism as the emperors abandoned the pretense of the republic and openly embraced their role as absolute rulers the emperor diocletian is known for formalizing this shift and introducing a tetrarchy system that briefly involved multiple coemperors ruling different regions of the empire ultimately however the imperial structure reverted to a single emperor as the supreme autocrat with elaborate court ceremonies and complex administrative structures to reinforce their powerthe roman empire persisted in the west until the fall of rome in  ce while the eastern roman empire also known as the byzantine empire lasted until the fall of constantinople in  ce the byzantine empire also had an autocratic government with the emperor playing a dominant role in both secular and ecclesiastical matters

andrew johnsons legacy as president is often overshadowed by his impeachment trial and the tumultuous reconstruction period that followed the american civil war johnson who served as the th president of the united states from  to  took office after the assassination of abraham lincoln despite the challenges johnson did have some noteworthy accomplishments and events that defined his presidency presidential reconstruction johnson took a moderate approach to postcivil war reconstruction advocating for a swift restoration of the southern states to the union with relatively lenient terms he issued a series of proclamations that began the process of reconstruction and pardoned many former confederates veto power johnson was very active in using his veto power although congress often overrode his vetoes he vetoed bills that he believed encroached on presidential authority or went against his conciliatory approach to the south for instance johnson vetoed the civil rights act of  which was designed to protect the rights of african americans but congress overrode his veto alaska purchase although not initiated by johnson himself during his presidency the united states purchased alaska from russia in  this became known as sewards folly named after secretary of state william h seward but it was later recognized as a significant acquisition due to its vast resources foreign policy johnsons administration dealt with foreign policy issues like the french intervention in mexico with the civil war over the us insisted that france withdraw its forces supporting emperor maximilian in mexico invoking the monroe doctrine france eventually complied leading to the restoration of the mexican republic attempting to reduce the national debt johnson tried to reduce the national debt that had ballooned during the civil war by advocating fiscal responsibility and curbing government spending opposition to the fourteenth amendment johnson opposed the fourteenth amendment which granted citizenship to all persons born or naturalized in the united states and guaranteed equal protection under the law despite his opposition the amendment was passed by congress and ratified by the states during his presidencydespite these actions johnsons presidency is often characterized by his contentious relationship with congress especially radical republicans who favored more stringent measures for reconstruction and protection of freed slaves rights his opposition to key reconstruction legislation led to his impeachment by the house of representatives he was the first american president to be impeached ultimately he was acquitted by one vote in the senate and therefore avoided removal from officehistorians often rank johnson among the least effective and least popular presidents largely due to his handling of postcivil war reconstruction and his failure to protect the rights of newly emancipated african americans

determining the best tour to egypt depends on various factors including your personal interests preferences budget and the amount of time you have available egypt has a lot to offer and tours can range from historical and archaeological explorations to leisurely cruises down the river nile heres how to find a tour thats right for you classic historical tours – these tours focus on ancient egyptian history they typically include visits to iconic sites such as the pyramids of giza the sphinx the egyptian museum the valley of the kings and the temples of karnak and luxor they might also include a visit to abu simbel nile river cruises – a cruise down the nile river is a relaxing way to see many of egypts ancient monuments cruises typically run between luxor and aswan and some may include stops at edfu and kom ombo this is an excellent way to see a number of sites without the need to pack and unpack at each location adventure tours – for the more adventurous traveler there are tours that include activities like desert safaris scuba diving in the red sea hot air balloon rides over luxor and treks to mount sinai cultural and local life tours – these tours highlight modern egyptian life offering deeper cultural experiences they might include visits to local markets small villages or cultural shows allinclusive packages – these are often the best deal in terms of convenience and price encompassing flights hotels transfers and guided tours custom and private tours – if you want a more personalized experience consider booking a private or custom tour where you can tailor your itinerary to suit your specific interests budget vs luxury tours – determine your budget beforehand as tours can vary widely in cost from budgetfriendly group packages to luxurious private tourswhen looking for the best tour consider these tips check reviews look for recent reviews of tour companies and guides customization see if the company allows you to customize your trip group size consider whether you prefer a large group tour a small group or a private tour as this affects your experience guides ensure youll have knowledgeable and certified egyptologists as guides inclusions and exclusions be clear on what is included in the tour price meals entrance fees transportation etc certifications look for tour companies that are certified and recognized by tourism authoritiesremember that the best time to visit egypt is during the cooler months from october to april summers can be extremely hot especially in upper egypt luxor and aswan many tour operators offer galileo galilei often known simply as galileo was a pioneering italian astronomer physicist and polymath who became famous for several reasons astronomical observations galileo made significant discoveries using a telescope which at the time was a relatively new invention that he did not invent but significantly improved upon in  and  his observations revolutionized the understanding of our cosmic neighborhood he discovered the four largest moons of jupiter io europa ganymede and callisto which are now known as the galilean moons he also observed the phases of venus the craters and mountains on the moon sunspots and the stellar makeup of the milky way heliocentric support galileo was a strong proponent of the heliocentric model of the solar system as originally proposed by copernicus which suggested that the earth and other planets revolve around the sun his observations provided strong evidence for this theory especially the phases of venus which could not be explained by the geocentric model that placed the earth at the center of the universe this advocacy put him in direct conflict with the dominant views of the catholic church at the time conflict with the church galileos support of heliocentrism led to accusations of heresy and he was eventually tried by the roman catholic inquisition in  he was forced to recant his views and was placed under house arrest for the remainder of his life his trial and condemnation became emblematic of the conflict between religious dogma and scientific inquiry contributions to physics beyond his astronomical achievements galileo is also renowned for his contributions to physics he studied the laws of motion and is credited with foundational work in the subject including the formulation of the law of inertia which later influenced newtons first law of motion he performed experiments that debunked the aristotelian physics of the time such as the famous though possibly apocryphal demonstration that objects of different masses fall at the same rate in the absence of air resistance when dropped from the leaning tower of pisa scientific method galileo is also famed for his application and development of the scientific method he emphasized the importance of systematic observation experimentation and the mathematical description of natural phenomena his approach laid the groundwork for modern experimental scientific methodology published works his published works most notably sidereus nuncius starry messenger in  about his astronomical discoveries and dialogue concerning the two chief world systems in  which presented arguments for both the ptolemaic geocentric and copernican heliocentric systems were also pivotal in his rise to famethrough galileos work and his staunch defense of his findings he helped usher in the new era of modern science earning him the title father of modern science his contributions continue to be celebrated for their profound impact on human understanding of the natural world

the scarlet letter by nathaniel hawthorne is a complex novel with multiple themes some of which include sin guilt and redemption a central theme of the novel involves the nature of sin the effects of sin on the soul and psyche and the possibility of redemption hawthorne explores how sin affects the sinner and those around them differently using the characters of hester prynne arthur dimmesdale and roger chillingworth to show different responses to sin and guilt isolation and alienation hester prynnes experience of wearing the scarlet letter a for adulterer isolates her from the puritan society the novel delves into the effects of this social isolation on her character and individuality hypocrisy and judgment the novel critiques the hypocrisy of a society that claims to uphold moral values while punishing individuals harshly for their missteps it shows how quick the community is to judge and scorn hester for her sin while many harbor their own secrets women’s role and identity hester prynnes character challenges the submissive role expected of women in puritan society instead of being entirely crushed by her punishment she becomes a strong independent woman who defies the patriarchal norms of her community public vs private penitence the theme of public versus private punishment is a recurring theme in the novel as hester is publicly shamed for her sin while dimmesdale suffers privately this contrast underscores the idea that the severest form of punishment might be the one imposed by personal conscience rather than that which is socially ordained the nature of evil through the character of chillingworth the novel explores the nature of evil as it manifests in the desire for revenge and how that desire can consume and destroy an individualhawthornes novel uses these themes to explore the moral and societal issues of thcentury puritan new england but the questions it raises remain relevant in other contexts as well making the scarlet letter a timeless tale of human nature and society

thomas alva edison was one of the most prolific inventors in history holding  us patents in his name as well as many patents in the united kingdom france and germany here is a list of some of his most notable inventions and contributions phonograph  one of edisons most famous inventions the phonograph was the first device to record and reproduce sound making it a precursor to the modern record player and various other music playback devices light bulb  although he did not invent the first electric light bulb edison made significant improvements developing a practical and longlasting incandescent bulb with a carbon filament which was commercially viable motion picture camera  edisons kinetograph was one of the first cameras designed to record motion pictures along with the kinetoscope viewer this invention laid the foundation for the motion picture industry electric power distribution  edison developed a complete system of electric power generation and distribution which he installed in new york city this was a direct current dc system which later competed with nikola teslas alternating current ac system carbon microphone  this microphone used in early telephones greatly improved the clarity and volume of telephone communication alkaline storage battery  edison developed a durable storage battery that had a variety of uses including powering electric vehicles such as delivery trucks and trains fluoroscope  edison invented a machine that used xrays to take radiographs however after his assistant suffered severe health effects from radiation exposure edison abandoned his research in this field stock ticker  edison improved upon the stock ticker technology which provided uptodate stock market information to finance professionals electric vote recorder  one of edisons early inventions designed to speed up the voting process in legislative bodies however it was never adopted tasimeter  a device edison designed to measure small changes in temperature which he attempted to use to detect the heat of the sun during an eclipsethese are just a few examples of edisons many inventions his broad range of interests led to developments in fields that include telecommunications audio recording motion pictures battery technology and more edisons work helped propel technological advances that shaped the modern world

the soviet union officially known as the union of soviet socialist republics ussr which existed from  until its dissolution in  had a oneparty socialist government based on the communist ideology of marxismleninism the government was highly centralized and authoritarianpolitical power was held by the communist party which controlled all aspects of the state society and economy the partys top leadership particularly its general secretary was the de facto highest authority in the country while there were other political organizations and socalled independent institutions these were all controlled by or subservient to the communist partythe structure of the government included supreme soviet it was nominally the highest legislative body and was supposed to represent the will of the people but it mostly acted as a rubberstamp institution for decisions made by the communist partys leadership council of ministers this served as the governments executive branch managing the daytoday affairs of the state and the implementation of policy politburo this was the principal policymaking committee of the communist party and the true center of political power where the most important state decisions were madethe soviet unions government also maintained an extensive state security apparatus most famously represented by the kgb which worked to suppress dissent and control citizens through various means of surveillance censorship and political repression the states official ideology permeated all aspects of life with a focus on state ownership and centralized planning of the economy

the chernobyl disaster which occurred on april   is considered the worst nuclear power plant accident in history both in terms of cost and casualties it happened at the chernobyl nuclear power plant near the nowabandoned town of pripyat in northern ukrainian ssr soviet union approximately  km  miles north of kievthe catastrophe began during a latenight safety test simulating a power outage aimed at understanding how long turbines would spin and provide power to the main circulating pumps following a loss of main electrical power supply due to a combination of inherent reactor design flaws and the reactor operators arranging the core in a manner contrary to the checklist for the test reactor  became unstableas the operators proceeded with the test they inadvertently caused the reactor to reach dangerously low power levels attempts to increase power poor operating conditions which were unstable and contrary to the test parameters ultimately led to an extremely rapid power increase the reactors emergency shutdown mechanism scram was activated but a design flaw in the control rods caused a dramatic power surgethe power surge led to an explosion of steam causing a rupture of the reactor pressure vessel and a series of steam and hydrogen explosions these blasts blew the tonne steel and concrete lid off the reactor allowing the radioactive contents to escape into the atmosphere the intense fires that followed released radioactive contaminants for ten daysthe initial explosion killed two plant workers over the next few weeks  more people died due to acute radiation sickness the disaster also led to the evacuation and resettlement of over  people from severely contaminated areas the number of longterm health effects including cancer attributed to the chernobyl accident is a subject of scientific discussion with estimates varying widelythe international community led by the soviet union initiated a massive cleanup campaign that involved hundreds of thousands of cleanup workers liquidators who were exposed to substantial radiation doses it included the construction of a massive steel and concrete sarcophagus called the chernobyl shelter fund to encase the destroyed reactor and contain radioactive materialin november  an additional confinement structure named the new safe confinement was completed and placed over the old sarcophagus to further contain the radioactive material and allow for the eventual deconstruction of the old shelterthe chernobyl disaster raised concerns about nuclear safety leading to changes in safety culture and the regulatory environment for nuclear power technology it compelled the soviet government to become more open known as glasnost and led to changes in the international nuclear power industrys regulatory and safety standards

the akkadian empire which arose sometime around the th century bce under the leadership of sargon the great was the first empire to unify a number of individual citystates and regions under a single ruler it included territories of the sumerian citystates in lower mesopotamia as well as extending to parts of the levant and perhaps parts of anatolia and the iranian plateauat its peak the akkadian empire stretched from the persian gulf through the tigris and euphrates river valleys encompassing what is now southern iraq parts of modernday syria turkey and iran the core of the empire was in the region of akkad whose precise location is still unknown but thought to be near the center of presentday iraq north of ancient sumer near the city of babylonthe akkadian empire is known for significant cultural political and technological advances it established a pattern of imperial governance that would influence successor states in the region saw the introduction of the akkadian language as a lingua franca along with sumerian and witnessed advancements in architecture art and the bureaucratic administration that included the use of the earliest known form of written documentation using cuneiform script on clay tabletsthe akkadian empire eventually collapsed around the nd century bce likely due to a combination of internal strife invasions and possibly climatic changes resulting in a period of aridity leading to the gutian period and setting the stage for the rise of the third dynasty of ur and later mesopotamian civilizations

thor heyerdahl – was a norwegian adventurer and ethnographer with a background in biology geography and anthropology he is most famous for his kontiki expedition in  where he sailed a balsa wood raft from south america to the polynesian islands the purpose of the expedition was to demonstrate that ancient people could have made long sea voyages creating contacts between separate cultures this was a radical idea at the time because many scholars believed that the islands were too remote to have been settled by people from the continental landmassesthe kontiki raft was named after the inca sun god viracocha who was also known as kontiki heyerdahls journey covered  kilometers  miles across the pacific ocean starting from callao in peru and concluding  days later on the raroia atoll in the tuamotu archipelago the successful voyage was widely reported and made thor heyerdahl an international figure it also inspired a book the kontiki expedition by raft across the south seas and a documentary film which won an academy awardbeyond the kontiki expedition heyerdahl conducted other notable experiments and research that contributed to our understanding of migration culture and early human settlement patterns these included the ra and tigris projects aimed at demonstrating the possibility of contact between ancient civilizations in africa and the americas and connections between mesopotamia and the indus valley respectivelyheyerdahls theories about population movements and his methods have been both widely lauded and criticized while many traditional archaeologists and historians dismissed some of his theories due to a lack of concrete evidence his adventurous spirit and handson approach to testing his theories made a significant impact on the publics imagination later expanded by president john f kennedy to include almost all exports to cuba on february   effectively creating a full economic embargoover the years the embargo has been codified into law with buddhism does not have a single holy book equivalent to the bible or the quran instead buddhist teachings are contained in a vast collection of ancient texts known as the pāli canon for theravada buddhists and the mahayana sutras for mahayana buddhiststhe pāli canon also known as the tipitaka or tripitaka meaning three baskets is considered the most authoritative record of the original teachings of siddhartha gautama who became known as the buddha it is divided into three sections the vinaya pitaka the code of monastic discipline the sutta pitaka discourses and the abhidhamma pitaka philosophical and doctrinal analysismahayana buddhists also revere other texts such as the lotus sutra the heart sutra and the diamond sutra among many others these texts expand on the teachings found in the pāli canon and introduce additional concepts and practicesit is important to note that while these texts are considered sacred buddhists do not view them in the same light as the word of god as in some theistic religions instead they are regarded as teachings and guidelines to help practitioners on their path to enlightenment

thomas robert malthus was an english cleric scholar and influential economist born on february   and died on december   he is best known for his work on population growth and his contributions to the field of demographics malthus fundamentally changed the way individuals thought about the economy and demography with his most famous work an essay on the principle of population first published in in his essay malthus argued that population growth would always tend to outrun the food supply and that without restraint or checks such as disease famine war or moral restraint delayed marriage and celibacy populations would lead to a decrease in the living standards his theory is often summarized by the phrase malthusian trap which refers to the potential for population to increase at a geometric rate     while resources especially food grow at an arithmetic rate     leading to a situation where the environment cannot sustain the populationmalthuss ideas were both influential and controversial they were taken into consideration by economists and policymakers and sparked much debate on issues of social policy and family planning his work laid the foundation for the fields of demography and population studies and had a profound impact on the theories of charles darwin and alfred russel wallace in the development of the theory of natural selectionover time malthuss predictions have been both criticized and reexamined particularly as technological advances have alleviated some of the constraints on food production that he identified however his ideas continue to drive discussions on sustainable development environmental policy and population dynamics

constitution for his pivotal role in drafting and promoting the united states constitution and the bill of rightsmadison was born in port conway virginia and grew up on a tobacco plantation he later attended the college of new jersey now princeton university a brilliant thinker and a meticulous scholar madison became heavily involved in the revolutionary cause against great britainduring and after the american revolutionary war madison served in the continental congress and the virginia state legislature he worked closely with alexander hamilton and john jay to write the federalist papers a series of essays that played a crucial role in convincing states to ratify the constitutionmadison was a leading architect of the new us constitution which established the framework for the federal government and resolved many of the issues that arose under the articles of confederation at the constitutional convention of  madison argued for a strong central government while still emphasizing the importance of individual and state rightswhen the new government was formed madison served as a member of the us house of representatives and as the secretary of state under president thomas jefferson as secretary of state he supervised the louisiana purchase which doubled the size of the united statesas president madison led the united states into the war of  against great britain the war was partly in response to british restrictions on us trade and americas interest in expanding its territory although the war ended in a stalemate it helped to establish the united states as a sovereign nation and later bolstered a sense of national pride known as the era of good feelingsmadisons presidency also dealt with internal issues such as the charter of the second bank of the united states and various infrastructure projects known as the american system after his presidency madison retired to his virginia plantation montpelier and remained active in public affairs he was a powerful voice against the secessionist sentiments that were rising in the southern states but did not live to see the civil warjames madisons contributions to american constitutional democracy and call centre users lose patiencecustomers trying to get through to call centres are getting impatient and quicker to hang up a survey suggestsonce past the welcome message callers on average hang up after just  seconds of listening to canned music the drop in patience comes as the number of calls to call centres is growing at a rate of  every year customers are getting used to the idea of an always available society says cara diemont of it firm dimension data which commissioned the survey however call centres also saw a sharp increase of customers simply abandoning calls she says from just over  in  to a record  during last year when automated phone message systems are taken out of the equation where customers have to pick their way through multiple options and messages the number of abandoned calls is even higher  a sixth of all callers give up rather than wait one possible reason for the lack in patience ms diemont says is the fact that more customers are calling on the move using their mobile phonesthe surge in customers trying to get through to call centres is also a reflection of the centres growing range of tasks once a call centre may have looked after mortgages now its agents may also be responsible for credit cards insurance and current accounts ms diemont says problems are occurring because increased responsibility is not going handinhand with more training the survey foundin what dimension data calls an alarming development the average induction time for a call centre worker fell last year from  to just  days leaving agents not equipped to deal with customers this ms diemont warns is scary and not good for the bottom line either poor training frustrates both call centre workers and customers as a result call centres have a high churn rate with nearly a quarter of workers throwing in the towel every year which in turn forces companies to pay for training new staff resolution rates  the number of calls where a customers query is resolved to mutual satisfaction  are running at just  when the query is passed on to a second or third person  a specialist or manager  rates rise to about  but that is still well below the industry target of an  resolution ratesuggestions that outsourcing  relocating call centres to lowcost countries like india or south africa  is to blame are wrong ms diemont saysthere are no big differences in wait time and call resolution between call centres based in europe or north america and those in developing countries around the world you can make call centres perform anywhere if you have good management and the right processes in place she says however companies that decide to offshore their operations are driven not just by cost considerations only  of them say that saving money is the main consideration when closing domestic call centre operations half of them argue that workers in other countries offer better skills for the money but not everybody believes that outsourcing and offshoring are the solution nearly twothirds of all firms polled for the survey have no plans to offshore their call centres they give three key reasons for not making the move call centre operations are part of their business core function   they are worried about the risk of going abroad   they fear that they will damage their brand if they join the offshoring drive the survey was conducted by sunovate on behalf of dimension data and is based on indepth questionnaires of  call centres in  countries and five continents what are your experiences with call centres are you happy to listen to vivaldi or greensleeves or do you want an immediate response and if you work in a call centre did your training prepare you for your job

fed chief warning on us deficitfederal reserve chairman alan greenspan has warned that allowing huge us budget deficits to continue could have severe consequencesspeaking to the house budget committee he urged congress to take action to cut the deficit such as increasing taxes while the us economy is growing at a reasonably good pace he warned that budget concerns were clouding the economic outlook for the us pension and healthcare costs posed the greatest risks to the economy he saidthe government program faces severe financial strains in coming decades as the massive babyboom generation retires i fear that we may have already committed more physical resources to the babyboom generation in its retirement years than our economy has the capacity to deliver if existing promises need to be changed those changes should be made sooner rather than later mr greenspan said he also warned that unless the nation sees unprecedented rises in productivity retirement and health programmes would need significant changes he called on congress to cut promised benefits for retirees as the promised benefits for the soontoretire baby boom generation were much larger than the government could affordmeanwhile any move to narrow the deficit gap by raising taxes could pose a significant risk to the economy by dampening growth and spending he added he also urged congress to reinstate lapsed rules that require tax cuts and spending to be offset elsewhere in the budget in an effort to prevent the us heading further into the red despite the dire warnings mr greenspan did offer some good news for the short term as us growth gathers steam and incomes rise that should lead to a narrowing of the deficit recent increases in defence and homeland security spending were also not expected to continue indefinitely which should cut some costs since president george w bush came to office the federal budget has swung from a record surplus to a record deficit of bn last year

economy stronger than forecastthe uk economy probably grew at a faster rate in the third quarter than the  reported according to bank of england deputy governor rachel lomaxprivate sector business surveys suggest a stronger economy than official estimates ms lomax said other surveys collectively show a rapid slowdown in uk house price growth she pointed out this means that despite a strong economic growth base rates will probably stay on hold at  official data comes from the office for national statistics ons though reliable ons data takes longer to publish so now the boe is calling for faster delivery of data so it can make more effective policy decisions recent work by the bank has shown that private sector surveys add value even when preliminary ons estimates are available ms lomax said in a speech to the north wales business clubthe ons is due to publish its second estimate of third quarter growth on friday the mpc judges that overall growth was a little higher in the third quarter than the official data currently indicate ms lomax said the bank said successful monetary policy depends on having good information rachel lomax cited the late s as an example of a time when weak economic figures were published but substantially revised upwards years laterthe statistical fog surrounding the true state of the economy has proved a particularly potent breeding ground for policy errors in the past she said improving the quality of national statistics is the single the best way of making sure the monetary policy committee mpc makes the right decisions she said the bank of england is working in tandem with the ons to improve the quality and speed of delivery of data her remarks follow criticism from the house of lords economic affairs committee which said the mpc had held interest rates too high given that inflation was way below the  targeta slowdown in the housing market and this years surge in oil prices has made economic forecasting all the more tricky leading to a more uncertain outlook this year rising oil prices and a significant slowdown in the housing market have awoken bad memories of the s and s ms lomax said the mpc will be doing well if it can achieve the same stability over the next decade as we have enjoyed over the past  years decisions on interest rates are made after the mpc gathers together the range of indicators available every month the clearest signals come when all indicators are pointing the same direction ms lomax intimated in economic assessment there is safety in numbers

rate of  in december  its highest level in six months data on wednesday also showed manufacturing output rose at its fastest rate since may last month reinforcing a view that economic growth was stronger than forecastsand recent house surveys from the halifax and nationwide have indicated prices are still rising albeit at a slower pace than in recent years philip shaw chief economist at investec securities said he believed rates would remain at  for the rest of the year although strong economic data could lead to a further hike the economic landscape has changed quite considerably over the last couple of months  he said growth appears stronger and the mpc may become more concerned about inflation trends howard archer economist at global insight said the mpc may well consider that the balance of risks to the growth and inflation outlook have moved from the downside to the upsidebusiness groups welcomed the mpcs widelyexpected move to leave rates on hold and cautioned against further rises the british chambers of commerce bcc said it was concerned by the clamour in some quarters for early interest rate increases we believe that these demands should be firmly they are also about ensuring europe can continue to compete as an equal with the growing economic giants of asia india and china as well as with the economic might of the united states thats why there was a tone of urgency in the report out on wednesday by the former dutch prime minister wim kok mr kok was commissioned by the european commission in march this year to assess how far the eu has come towards meeting the lisbon targets five years on from their inception his conclusion was simple too many of the targets will be seriously missedlisbon risks becoming a synonym for missed objectives and failed promises his report said the status quo is not an optionat risk in the medium to long run is nothing less than the sustainability of the society europe has built it said the report comes at a time when europes competitive position is waning the eus economic growth rate is projected to be  this year and  next while there has been growth in overall employment rates in europe productivity lags behind that of the us but meeting the lisbon targets requires a political commitment that no eu member state has volunteered so far that has in part been due to the state of the global economy in the past few yearsas mr koks report noted the ink had scarcely dried on the lisbon agreement before the worldwide stock market bubble imploded the us suffered two years of economic slowdown and recession and the european economy followed suitthe circumstances werent conducive to creating the  million new jobs promised by eu leaders in lisbon in  neither were they conducive to getting governments to spend more on research and development money needed if the eu was to meet its target of becoming a socalled knowledgebased economy the lisbon vision is a compelling one but in order to do it society has to change said paul hofheinz of the lisbon council a brusselsbased citizen action group what you find is that a lot of people have been fighting change you find trade unions fighting change but also the employers associations even though they tell you theyre in favour of change many are actually pushing for less competition more subsidy and less free market activitybut part of the problem was also linked to the original targets set out in lisbon five years ago targets have a habit of coming back to haunt you and in the lisbon case they covered too much according to the wim report economic growth and job creation were linked to issues ranging from environmental protection to social inclusion and even safety at sea the agenda was just too broad and as a result nothing was prioritisedlisbon is about everything and thus about nothing the kok report said everybody is responsible and thus no one thats why the kok report recommends that the lisbon targets be narrowed down to  key indicators with an emphasis on creating jobs and economic growth it also recommends that the european commission draw up a league table which ranks countries according to the steps theyre taking towards meeting the targets effectively naming shaming and faming rhetoric and delivery dont necessarily go hand in hand mr kok said in a press conference alongside the publication of his report we dont have the luxury anymore just to exchange politeness with one anotheron one point mr kok was very clear the european union should not try to emulate the us economy the european economic and social model needs to change but not so much so that social and environmental issues take a backseat to economic growth in that sense the lisbon agenda is sailing into unchartered waters the kok report tries to do away with a belief that jobs need to be sacrificed at the altar of economic growth its very ambitious said john palmer political director at the european policy centre a brusselsbased thinktank this is something that no advanced economy in the world has tried to do its going to require quite new and innovative policies but some analysts believe that the kok report doesnt come up with the sort of innovative policies and thinking needed to make the lisbon targets a reality for example it recommends putting in place policies which encourage women and older people to remain in the workforce but it doesnt say how companies should be convinced to do this it will be up to the incoming president of the european commission jose manuel barroso to adopt mr koks recommendations and press them on eu governments mr barroso has said that the eus competitiveness will be his top priority he expects his fiveyear term in office to be judged on europes success in meeting the lisbon agenda

gsk aims to stop aids profiteersone of the worlds largest manufacturers of hivaids drugs has launched an initiative to combat the smuggling of cheaper pills  supplied to poorer african countries  back into europe for resale at far higher pricethe company glaxosmithkline is to alter the packaging and change the colour of the pills currently provided to developing nations under a humanitarian agreement it is estimated that drugs companies are losing hundreds of millions of dollars each year as a result of the diversion of their products in this way this is a very sensitive area for the big drugs companies they want to maintain their profits but have been put under tremendous pressure to provide cheap antiaids drugs to the worlds poorest nationsthe result is that drugs supplied to africa are now more than thirty times cheaper than those sold in europe bringing these medicines within the reach of millions of hivpositive africans through their governments health care systemsbut the wide difference in price also means that there are big gains to be made from illegally diverting these cheaper drugs back into wealthier countries and reselling them at a higher price glaxosmithkline believes that by coating the pills destined for africa in a red dye and adding new identification codes both onto the pills and on the packaging then this trade can be substantially reduced the company says that it will then be possible to identify specific distributors in africa who have resold humanitarian drugs for profit as well as those suppliers in europe that have also been involved in the trade glaxo says distribution of the newlook drugs has already begun and that their chemical content is identical to those currently being sold in europe

us regulator to rule on pain drugus food and drug regulators will decide on friday whether to recommend the sale of painkillers that have been linked to a high risk of heart attack and strokethe food and drug administration fda advisory panel will give its verdict after hearing evidence for three days the painkillers  called cox inhibitors  are sold under brand names such as celebrex and vioxx vioxx was withdrawn from shops last year but merck said it would consider selling it if it gets fda approval the fda has been asked to decide if the benefits to patients justify the increased risksputting vioxx back on the shelves is likely to boost profits at merck and make easier any legal battles with people who claim to have been injured by the drug analysts saidmerck voluntarily stopped sales of vioxx on  september a move which caused the firms fourthquarter earnings to slide to bn â£m from bn a year earlier mercks shares tumbled more than  on the news and the company has had to set aside millions of dollars to cover the cost of vioxxrelated litigation alarm bells were rung by a research note called approve which showed that the risk of heart attack and stroke doubled in patients who had been taking the drug for at least  months the cox inhibitors were developed by drug companies including merck and pfizer because they cause users fewer stomach problems than other painkillerspfizer is still selling its celebrex and bextra products though investigations have suggested that they may also be harmful to the heart mercks announcement of a possible reintroduction of vioxx caught analysts by surprise mercks head of research peter kim said that it withdrew vioxx based on the information that was available to us at the time knowing there were alternative therapies he went on to say that things have since changed in the light of new reports given this new information its is not clear that the cardiovascular risk observed in approve makes vioxx unique in the class of similar drugs marketed in the us mr kim explainedon thursday david graham from the fdas office of drug safety told the advisory panel that there really doesnt appear to be a need for cox inhibitors according to calculations presented to the us senate by dr graham in november vioxx may be linked to as many as to  american deaths facing stem criticism for its handling of the vioxx case the fda said on tuesday that it will create an independent body to oversee the safety of drugs already in the market place european regulators meanwhile ruled on thursday that patients who have had heart disease or a stroke should not take cox inhibitors the european medicines agency also said doctors should be cautious about giving the drugs to patients who have risk factors for heart disease

cuba winds back economic clockfidel castros decision to ban all cash transactions in us dollars in cuba has once more turned the spotlight on cubas ailing economyall conversions between the us dollar and cubas convertible peso will from  november be subject to a  tax cuban citizens who receive money from overseas and foreign visitors who change dollars in cuba will be affected critics of the measure argue that it is a step backwards reflecting the cuban presidents desire to increase his control of the economy and to clamp down on private enterprise in a live television broadcast announcing the measure president castros chief aide said it was necessary because of the united states increasing economic aggression the ten percent obligation applies exclusively to the dollar by virtue of the situation created by the new measures of the us government to suffocate our country he saidthe bush administration has taken an increasingly harsh line on cuba in recent months president bushs government which has been a strong supporter of the yearold trade embargo on cuba introduced even tighter restrictions on cuba in maycubans living in the us are now limited to one visit to cuba every three years and they can only send money to their immediate relatives a leading expert on the cuban economy says that castros tax plan smacks more of a desperate economic measure than a political gesture i think it is primarily an effort to raise some cash says jose barrionuevo head of strategy for latin american emerging markets for barclays capital it underscores the fact that the economy is in very bad shape and the government is looking for sources of revenuethe tax will hit the families of cuban exiles hardest as they benefit from the money their displaced relatives send home this money known as remittances can amount to as much as bn a year those remaining in cuba will have to pay the tax their relatives abroad may choose to send money in other currencies which are not subject to the tax such as euros or increase their dollar payments to compensate however many of cubans poorest citizens could be worse off as a result the tax will also affect the two million tourists who visit cuba every year particularly those americans who continue to defy a ban on travel therecubas tourist industry has been one of its few economic success stories over the last ten years and according to the un economic commission for latin america is now worth bn to the countrythe tax is designed to provide muchneeded revenue for cubas cashstrapped economy cuba badly needs dollars to pay for essential items such as food fuel and medicine much of cubas basic infrastructure is in a state of disrepair in recent weeks cuba has suffered its most serious power cuts in a decade and there have also been water shortages in parts of the island cubas economy had staged a modest recovery during the mid s as the collapse of the soviet union forced it to embrace foreign capital decentralise trade and permit limited private enterprise however a decline in foreign tourism since  periodic hurricanes and the increasing costs of importing oil have put a strain on the economy it has however yet to be seen if the tax will provide a solution to the governments economic problems the tax could fuel an active black market in currency trading mr barrionuevo said the main impact could be that it will create a black market which you typically see in countries like venezuela which have restrictions on capital he says mr barrioneuvo says the measure could be dropped if it has a damaging effect on economic activity it is intended to be a permanent measure but i am not sure it can last too long

in kirkcaldy fife the adam smith lecture celebrates the author of s wealth of nations which became a bible of capitalism dr greenspan was invited by chancellor gordon brown whose minister father john used to preach at the st bryce kirk church mr brown introduced dr greenspan to the  invited guests as the the worlds greatest economist dr greenspan  who has been in the uk to attend the g meeting in london said the world could never repay the debt of gratitude it owed to smith whose genius he compared to that of mozarthe said the philosopher was a towering contributor to the modern world kirkcaldy the birthplace in  of adam smith and by extension of modern economics is also of course where your chancellor was reared i am led to ponder to what extent the chancellors renowned economic and financial skills are the result of exposure to the subliminal intellectenhancing emanation in this area he continued smith reached far beyond the insights of his predecessors to frame a global view of how market economics just then emerging worked in so doing he supported changes in societal organisation that were to measurably enhance standards of livingdr greenspan said smiths revolutionary philosophy on human selfinterest laissezfaire economics and competition had been a force for good in the world the incredible insights of a handful of intellectuals of the enlightenment  especially with smith toiling in the environs of kirkcaldy  created the modern vision of people free to choose and to act according to their individual selfinterest he said following his lecture dr greenspan  who received an honorary knighthood from the queen at balmoral in   was awarded an honorary fellowship of the royal society of edinburgh he later opened an exhibition dedicated to smith in the atrium of fife college of further and higher education joyce johnston principal of the college said it is very fitting that the worlds premier economist delivered this lecture in tribute to the worlds first economist dr greenspan  who became chairman of the federal reserve for an unprecedented fifth term in june   will step down in january next year he has served under presidents george w bush bill clinton george bush and ronald reagan he was also chairman of the council of economic advisors to gerald ford

sales fail to boost high streetthe january sales have failed to help the uk high street recover from a poor christmas season a survey has foundstores received a boost from bargain hunters but trading then reverted to december levels the british retail consortium and accountants kpmg said sales in what is traditionally a strong month rose by  on a likeforlike basis compared with a year earlier consumers remain cautious over buying bigticket items like furniture said brc director general kevin hawkins higher interest rates and uncertainty over the housing market continue to take their toll on the retail sector the brc said but clothing and footwear sales were said to be generally better than december while department stores also had a good monthin the threemonths to january likeforlike sales showed a growth rate of  the same as in the three months to december the brc said following a relatively strong new years bank holiday trading then took a downward turn said mr hawkins even extending some promotions and discounts and the payday boost later in the month could not tempt customers the previous brc survey found christmas  was the worst for  years for retailers and according to office for national statistics data sales in december failed to meet expectations and by some counts were the worst since

yukos drops banks from court bidrussian oil company yukos has dropped the threat of legal action against five banks it had accused of involvement in the sale of its key yugansk unitstateowned rosneft bought the unit for bn â£bn after yukos was forced to sell assets to meet a bn tax bill yukos says the sale was illegal and is pursuing damages in a us court its lawyers now accept abn amro bnp paribas calyon jp morgan chase bank and dresdner kleinwort wasserstein were not involved in the sale financing however yukos still has an outstanding complaint against deutsche bank which it alleges to be the leader of a consortium that was behind a bid for yugansk by state gas monopoly gazprom the company has also accused gazprom the russian federation and two other russian firmsgazprom had been expected to win the december auction but ended up not bidding yugansk was sold to a littleknown shell company which in turn was bought by rosneft yukos claims its downfall was punishment for the political ambitions of its founder mikhail khodorkovsky the firm whose finance chief is now based in the us filed for bankruptcy in houston texas and sought a court injunction against the sale but deutsche bank has suggested yukos artificially manufactured a legal case to stop the sale of its main asset a hearing scheduled for february  and  will rule on whether the us court has jurisdiction in the case

venezuela reviews foreign dealsvenezuela is to review all foreign investment in its mining industries in an effort to strengthen its indigenous industrial outputpresident hugo chavez has ordered all existing contracts with foreign firms to be examined to see if they provide maximum benefits to the country the review will cover production of gold aluminium and iron ore although it excludes the countrys oil sector chavez has sought to extend the states role in all sectors of the economythe leftwing president is conducting a controversial review of land ownership in the country while also seeking to create a staterun telecoms firm to compete with foreignowned businesseshe has argued that major economic reforms are vital to improve the lives of venezuelas poorest citizens announcing the review of raw material production minister victor alvarez said the government would seek to transfer technology training capability and content from projects with foreign partners we are defending our national sovereignty over the use of our national resources which must serve the endogenous development of the nation mr alvarez said for this reason we are reviewing all memorandums of understanding all letters of intent all agreements that have been signed all contracts to check which of these comply with these directives everything absolutely everything has to be reviewedvenezuela has previously assured foreign companies with operations in the mineral rich country that it respects existing contracts however the government insisted that it needed to develop its own industrial infrastructure in order to create new jobs and lessen its reliance on foreign partners if we dont do this we are just going to carry on being slaves suppliers of raw materials all our lives and we will never develop our own productive capacity mr alvarez added companies from the united states canada france and switzerland all have substantial investments in venezuelas mining sector

g backs africa debt relief plang finance ministers have backed plans to write off up to  of the debts of some of the worlds poorest countriesuk chancellor gordon brown said the london meeting of the worlds seven richest nations would be remembered as the  debt relief summit some  countries could benefit after a casebycase review by bodies including the world bank and the imf he said but the us says it cannot support mr browns international finance facility to boost aid to developing countries bbc correspondents said the meeting had produced some movement towards the uks ambitions but much work was needed mr brown said it was a major breakthrough for the international organisations to offer up to  multilateral debt relief  the vast bulk of money owed by the poorest countrieswe could be at the beginning of the final stage of the process where the debts that were owed by the poorest countries built up over  or  years debts that are simply unpayable in the real world are finally taken care of he said he added it is the richest countries hearing the voices of the poor but he said they would insist on government reforms and the need for transparency tackling corruption and openness from both the poorest and richest nations bbc correspondent patrick bartlett said while it was an agreement in principle the organisations involved now have to look at how it would work in practice oxfam senior policy adviser max lawson welcomed the statement and said g ministers had passed the first hurdle of but he added they need to move quickly to turn their proposals into real change for the worlds poorest two million children will die needlessly between now and the next meeting in april if rich countries are going to keep their promises to tackle obscene poverty they need deliver be borrowed up front on financial marketsit is a key element of his proposals for a modern version of the marshall plan which brought us aid to rebuild europe after world war ii for the developing world mr brown said it was winning support every day and said a programme had been agreed to draw up more details in time for the g summit in july but us treasury undersecretary john taylor said the bn per year but south africa finance minister trevor manuel told the bbcs talking point programme what was needed was one approach with all wealthy nations on board he said much of the money pledged by the us had not yet been dispensedthe uk has made poverty in the poorest nations a key theme for its  presidency of the group of eight g which comprises the g and russia the g countries will meet at gleneagles in scotland at a dinner on friday night former south african president nelson mandela backed mr browns plan when he urged the finance chiefs to writeoff african debt and provide an extra bn
